Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Investigations of Electrospray Mass Spectrometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Richard Cole and his group at the University of New Orleans seek to investigate ways to improve electrospray (ES) mass spectrometry by building upon previous innovations in the development of anion attachment electrospray mass spectrometry; by detailed mapping of current and potential distributions within the ES emitter; and by optimization of detection of weakly-associated complexes in biological solutions. Efforts include development of "regioselective" anion attachment for selective detection of specific binding sites. This research will provide a means to improve the ability to detect and identify compounds such as steroids. A related aim is to improve the understanding of binding like that between tannins in food and proteins in saliva; this may provide a new means to gauge the loss in antioxidant capacity of potential tannin food additives. Derivation of a mathematical model to describe electrical current and potential within the electrospray device will advance the fundamental understanding of electrochemical processes in electrospray.

The project expands an existing partnership between the University of New Orleans and Xavier University of Louisiana. This endeavor will thus enlarge and enrich opportunities for graduate students and undergraduates (including members of underrepresented groups) at both institutions, specifically by widening exposure to mass spectrometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anion Attachment Mass Spectrometry for Improved Detection and Analysis of Steroids

 

Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry is the tool of choice for analysis of trace level compounds, even if they are present in complex mixtures. ESI-MS works well for polar compounds, but molecules that are neither acidic nor basic may be difficult to ionize and analyze because only weak signals will be generated. Nonpolar anabolic steroids are sports doping agents used for muscle growth that typically do not provide strong signals by electrospray ionization mass spectrometry, owing especially to the low polarity of the functional groups present on the molecules. Building on previous pioneering work by the Cole group on the development of anion attachment mass spectrometry, in this project, anion attachment mass spectrometry has been developed for steroids analysis, including anabolic steroids used in sports doping. A major finding of the project is that certain anabolic steroids, such as fluoxymesterone metabolite were detectable at levels as low as 10 ng/mL. This low level of detection has never been achieved for this anabolic steroid by any other method.

 

A further advantage of anion attachment mass spectrometry is the potential for regioselective attachment of the anion on multifunctional molecules which may be very useful to improve the selectivity in the multiple reaction monitoring method commonly employed in sports anti-doping analysis. Anions may indeed exhibit an increased tendency to bind to a specific electropositive site on a molecule in preference to others. This feature is evidenced by regiospecific decompositions of anionic  adducts in tandem mass spectrometry experiments and may be of importance to discriminate between steroids that have similar or isomeric structures and are thus difficult to distinguish using conventional analytical techniques. Thus, the work presented in this project has assessed the limits of detection obtainable employing anion attachment MS for actual steroids of abuse, while also weighing the factors that affect selectivity and quantification in mass spectrometric analyses using multiple reaction monitoring.

 

 

Identification of Soy-derived  Glyceollin Metabolites

 

Much of the health-related research concerning soy-derived products has been conducted on daidzein and genistein. Among the more recently studied soy-derived phytoestrogens are the glyceollins that are produced under stressed conditions (e.g., UV light exposure or infection by Aspergillus). Glyceollins, like the soy isoflavones, are non-steroid compounds, however, they possess a diphenolic substructure that exhibits similarities with estrogens. Recent investigations have proposed glyceollins as prevention or therapy candidates for breast, ovarian, and prostate cancers. Several propositions have been offered to explain the beneficial anti-tumoral activity of soy phytoestrogens; these include both estrogenic and non-estrogenic mechanisms. The potential anticancer benefits of glyceollins have been well documented, but its metabolism is not well understood, hence, our study examining glyceollin metabolism has made a large contribution to the detailed understanding of the breakdown of this phytoalexin.

 

Tandem mass spectrometry provided evidence for the glutathione conjugation pathway, and two metabolites were identified as cysteinyl- and cysteinylglyceine- conjugates of glyceollins with an addition of an oxygen. Based on a thorough analysis of samples derived primarily from in vivo administration of glyceollins, we proposed that the formation of the glutathione-derived metabolites is preceded by epoxide formation (Phase I metabolism). Oxygenated forms of mercapturic acid conjugates of glyceollins were found in rat feces, but not in rat plasma or urine. The possibility that glyceollin’s promising anti-proliferative effects are derived from an ability to induce phase II enzymes merits exploration.  With respect to the glucuronidation pathway, glucuronide conjugates of glyceollins were detected in rat plasma and urine, but not in feces. Unlike the glutathione conjugation pathway, glucuronidation was independent of phase I oxidation, as confirmed by in vitro glucuronidation of glyceollins by rat liver microsomes. A summary of all metabolism pathways has been presented.
